H0.text: Age of seedlings is the factor that should be varied among the five geranium pots in the studentâ€™s experiment investigating whether increasing the water supply will increase the number of flowers on the plant.

H1.text: Temperature of water is the factor that should be varied for the five geranium pots in the student's experiment, which aims to determine whether increasing the water supply will increase the number of flowers on each plant.

H2.text: Volume of water is the factor that should be varied for the five geranium pots in the student's experiment to determine whether increasing water supply increases the number of flowers on a plant.

H3.text: The number of hours in sunlight should be varied for the five geranium pots in the student's experiment to determine whether increasing the water supply will increase the number of flowers.

A4.text: Water pressure can be so low as to result only in a trickle of water or so high that it leads to damage to plumbing fixtures and waste of water.

A5.text: It is estimated that about half of the population of developing countries receives water on an intermittent basis.

A6.text: Geraniums will grow in any soil as long as it is not waterlogged.

A7.text: Controls eliminate alternate explanations of experimental results, especially experimental errors and experimenter bias.

A8.text: Randomization ensures that differences between groups are distributed equally, correcting for systematic errors.

A9.text: The capacity of the container can be anywhere from 0.5 litres (for indoor household plants) to 10 litres (for general garden use).

A10.text: At the end of the spout, a 'rose' can be placed to break up the stream of water into droplets, to avoid excessive water pressure on the soil or on certain delicate plants.
